oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Low Benthic Oxygen and High Internal Phosphorus-Loading are Strongly Associated With the Invasive Macrophyte Nitellopsis obtusa (starry stonewort) in a Large, Polymictic Lake
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harrow-Lyle, Tyler J.
Kirkwood, Andrea E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nitellopsis obtusa
invasive species
invasive macrophyte
aquatic invasion
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Lake Scugog is an important headwater to the Trent Severn-Waterway in Ontario, Canada. In recent years, notable ecosystem-level changes have occurred coinciding with the emergence of the non-native invasive charophyte <jats:italic>Nitellopsis obtusa</jats:italic>. Despite <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> arriving in North America in the early 1970s, studies documenting the impact of <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> on invaded ecosystems are scarce. Given the increasing dominance of <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> in inland waters of the Great Lakes basin, we investigated the ecosystem-level impacts of <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> in Lake Scugog over a 3-year period. We show for the first time a strong association between <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> occurrence and biomass with benthic anoxia in this shallow, polymictic lake. Benthic dissolved oxygen concentrations were significantly lower (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>-value < 0.001) at sites with <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> compared to sites without <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic>. Additionally, <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> biomass was a negative predictor of near-bed oxygen concentration (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> = 0.59, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>-value < 0.001). Knowing that anoxia can promote the internal loading of phosphorus, we measured soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) in the pore-water of sediments at each site, and found <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> biomass explained 90% of sediment pore-water SRP (<jats:italic>R</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> = 0.90, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>-value < 0.001). These notable associations between <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> and key lake elements indicates that <jats:italic>N. obtusa</jats:italic> may be acting as an ecosystem engineer in invaded lakes by altering the biogeochemical fate of oxygen and phosphorus.</jats:p>
